source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: Irradiation growth behavior of Zircaloy-2 and -4 was studied on specimens irradiated in the Experimental Breeder Reactor I to fluences of I.4 to $6 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ neutrons $( \mathsf { n } ) \cdot \mathsf { m } ^ { - 2 } \left( E > 1 \mathrm { \dot { M } e V } \right)$ in the temperature range 644 to ${ \tt 7 2 3 ~ \tt K }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: Measurements in the three principal directions on annealed and cold-worked/stress-relieved Zircaloy-2 slab materials provided evidence that growth is a constant-volume process up to about $\bf { 6 8 0 ~ K }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: The growth strains were shown to be determined by the crystallographic texture, that is, proportional to $( 1 - 3 f _ { d } ^ { c } )$ , where $\mathcal { f } _ { d } ^ { \mathcal { c } }$ is the fraction of basal poles, $f ^ { \epsilon }$ , in the direction d

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: The growth strains for annealed and cold-worked Zircaloy were large relative to previously reported data, were similar in magnitude, were strongly dependent on irradiation temperature, and varied linearly with fluence over the range investigated

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: Transmission electron microscopy on annealed Zircaloy-4 specimens revealed a few small voids and larger cavities, a grain boundary second phase, and dislocation loops, tangles, and arrays

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 (CI) was obtained as a $6 . 3 5 – \mathsf { c m }$ -thick slab with 20 percent cold work and contained 1100-ppm oxygen by weight

evidence_span: An anneal for one hour at $1 0 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ produced a nearly equiaxed grain structure with grain diameters between 15 and $1 9 \ \mu \ m$

evidence_span: The growth holders with flat specimens were encapsulated in 20 percent cold-worked, thin-walled 316 stainless steel tubing which was filled in an inert environment with sodium potassium as a heat-transfer medium.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk2
evidence_span: In the first irradiation, each capsule contained six holders and three thermal expansion difference (TED) temperature monitors while in the second irradiation each capsule had seven holders and two temperature monitors.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk2
evidence_span: The TED monitors were small stainless steel or Inconel-600 capsules filled with sodium which monitored the local maximum irradiation temperature through a correlation of the plastic deformation caused by the thermal expansion difference of the two metals with temperature.

evidence_span: in the EBR-II a fluence of approximately $3 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{n} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2}$ $E > 1 \mathrm{MeV} )$ produces one displacement per atom (dpa) in Zircaloy when the atomic displacement energy is taken to be $25 \mathrm{eV}$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk6
evidence_span: For a water reactor spectrum, it has been estimated that approximately $8 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{n} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2}$ is equivalent to 1 dpa when $33 \mathrm{eV}$ is taken to be the threshold

evidence_span: the damage per unit fluence for Zircaloy in the EBR-II is two to three times greater than in water reactors

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk7

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: A linear fit to the data showed the rate of increase in growth with temperature in annealed longitudinal material to be higher than the rate in 20 percent cold-worked material

evidence_span: Growth of both annealed and cold-worked Zircaloy could be described by a linear dependence on fluence with evidence that any transients, if present, are small in magnitude at these irradiation temperatures

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Measurements on specimens from the three principal directions of annealed and 20 percent cold-worked Zircaloy-2 slab materials provided evidence that growth is a constant-volume process in both types of material up to about $\yen 82 \textbf { K }$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Growth strains in a given direction in Zircaloy were shown to be determined by the crystallographic texture, that is, proportional to $( 1 - 3 f _ { d } ^ { c } )$ where $f _ { d } ^ { c }$ is the fraction of basal poles, $f ^ { c }$ , in the direction $d .$
